Information Processing by Cell Signalling Networks in Health and Disease 2026-27

Org Unit:Life Sciences NEW
Level:Level 6
Credits:15
Module Code:BIOS331
Delivery:Liverpool campus · Semester 1
 
In Programmes:Pharmacology BSc (Hons) 2024-25
Biomedical Sciences BSc (Hons) 2024-25
Microbiology and Infection BSc (Hons) 2024-25
Biochemistry BSc (Hons) 2024-25
Details
Module Title
Information Processing by Cell Signalling Networks in Health and Disease
Short Title
How do cells make decisions?
Module Code
BIOS331
Academic Year
2026-27
Org Unit
Life Sciences NEW
Delivery Locations
Liverpool campus
Delivery Periods
Semester 1
Credits
15
Level
Level 6

Terrence Gleave

15 Jan 2024, 10:47
External Examiner(s)
Leda Mirbahai
Continuing Professional Development
No
Maximum Places
350
Pre-requisites
Cellular Basis of Health and Disease 2025-26
HESA Cost Centres
Biosciences
Blurb
Overview
This module will build on concepts introduced in BIOS209: Cellular Basis of Health and Disease, to develop an in-depth understanding of modern ideas in cell signalling in both health and disease. It will provide students with the ability to access, collate and discuss the modern literature in cell signalling from both molecular and systems physiology perspectives. Students will be introduced to cutting-edge research about how signalling networks are dynamically integrated to control biological processes. Students will be taught aspects of fundamental cellular signalling processes, that are essential for life and often disrupted in disease.

The module will be taught through a series of 20 x 1 hour lectures and 10 x 1 hour tutorials, delivered by experts in their respective fields, and self-directed learning.

Assessment will be split into two cycles: Cycle 1 will be a written assignment, delivered online, based on data analysis and interpretation. Cycle 2 will be an open-book assessment, taken under exam conditions, in the form of extended written piece of work.
Educational Aims
This module aims to:
Develop knowledge and skills to enable the students to describe advanced concepts that are fundamental to modern ideas in cellular dynamics, biophysics and cell signalling from a systems physiology perspective covering both physiology and disease;

Develop the ability to apply, evaluate and interpret this knowledge and understanding;

Develop in students the ability to access, collate, critically evaluate, and discuss, in writing, the modern literature in cell signalling;

Enable students to acquire the skills required for interpretation of cell signalling experimental data and to integrate this knowledge in a physiological context.
Marketing Module Synopsis
Cell signalling networks allow individual cells to communicate with each other to coordinate their behaviour, maintain homeostasis, and respond to changes in their environment. This transfer of information from one cell to another, through the use of signalling molecules such as hormones, neurotransmitters, and growth factors is fundamental to modern ideas in cellular dynamics, biophysics and cell signalling in both health and disease.

This module will provide students with the ability to access, collate and discuss the modern literature in cell signalling from a systems physiology perspective by active research staff using relevant examples from their own research. Successful students will develop the skills required for interpretation of experimental cell signalling data. The module will be taught through a series of lectures and tutorials and will be assessed by both open book assessments. Cycle one will be an online assessment, with a focus on data analysis and interpretation; cycle 2 will be continuous assessment, under examination conditions, in the form of an extended piece of writing.
Outline Syllabus
The syllabus explores concepts fundamental to modern ideas in cell signalling. It will consider the major signalling pathways, and discuss specific examples of human diseases or physiological processes that utilise these generic pathways.

1. Feedback Mechanisms

Feedback mechanisms play a crucial role in regulating cell signalling pathways. Positive feedback amplifies the signal and increases the response, while negative feedback dampens the signal and reduces the response. This allows cells to fine-tune their responses to external stimuli and maintain a balance between opposing signals. Dynamic integration of feedback mechanisms fine tunes cellular outputs.

2. Spatial constraints

Cells are organised into specific tissues and organs, and signalling molecules must be able to reach their target cells within these structures. For example, nerve cells must communicate over long distances, while immune cells must communicate with neighbouring cells to coordinate their responses to pathogens.
Spatial and temporal regulation at a subcellular level, in order to control dynamic cellular processes, will also be considered.

3. Crosstalk between signalling pathways

Different pathways may interact with each other, either by amplifying or inhibiting their effects. This allows cells to integrate multiple signals and respond appropriately to complex stimuli.

4. Timing of Response

Many signalling pathways are activated rapidly in response to a stimulus, but then quickly deactivated to prevent overstimulation. This allows cells to respond to changing conditions and maintain proper function. Additionally, signalling pathways can be activated at specific times during development or in response to specific cues, allowing for precise control over cellular processes.
Themes 1-4 will allow students to appreciate a 4-dimensional model of cell signalling.

5. Therapeutic Intervention

Cellular Signalling is a complex process that involves feedback mechanisms, spatial constraints, crosstalk between pathways, and precise timing. Students will develop an understanding of how knowledge of these aspects of cell signalling can be harnessed to develop effective therapies for diseases that arise from dysregulation of these pathways.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Learning and teaching on this module will be delivered by live on-campus sessions (lectures & guided workshops), supplemented by asynchronous online preparatory material made available 1 week before the on-campus sessions.

Online Preparatory Material:  
This is the form of online reading, multimedia and small tasks to introduce key concepts and prepares students for the block of upcoming lectures.  
 
Lectures:  
The module will be taught through lectures with an emphasis towards student participation. These will cover the core module content and characterised by interactive group discussions and activities to enhance understanding of key concepts. 20 x 1 hour teaching sessions will be delivered over a twelve-week period.  
The synchronous on-campus lectures will provide new learning material but will also be an opportunity to discuss points raised in the asynchronous material. Focus will particularly be on research methodologies and data interrogation & interpretation. Interactive discussion will be encouraged through activities delivered through platforms such as Polls Everywhere and discussion boards.

Guided workshops/ Tutorials: These will provide opportunities for students to work with research staff in research-connected activities related to the summative assessments.

Self-directed learning: Guided and self-directed reading, reflection on learning, formative assessment (quizzes, discussion questions for synchronous sessions) and preparation for summative assessments.
The module is designed to incorporate the hallmarks of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework, in the following ways: 
 
Research-connected teaching: Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active/ connected scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence. Core concepts are contextualised with publications of recent scientific research. Assessment submissions from learners should be evidence-based by their exploration of primary literature, and suitably referenced.  

Inclusivity and accessibility: Resource templates use accessible fonts and colour schemes. Content is uploaded to the VLE in advance, in a format compatible with assistive technologies and checked proactively with Ally. Format adjustments are also available on request in accordance with specific learning disabilities and support plans. Lectures are recorded and available on the VLE. 

Active learning: Structured participation will be interactive, using quizzes (e.g. PollEverywhere, Mentimeter, Kahoot) and collaborative, interactive tools (e.g. Padlet, Miro). Formative exercises will provide students with regular feedback on their learning. 

Confidence: This is developed continuously throughout the module. Lectures are discursive and interactive, with learners contributing ideas and analysis to ongoing discussion. This builds confidence by creating a ‘safe space’ for sharing of ideas and expertise.  

Digital fluency: Digital fluency is encouraged through a combination of methods. The VLE is used for formative and summative assessment in the form of interactive quizzes. Assessment activity also requires students to develop competency with digital technology. 
 
Global citizenship: Organisms, their development, their varied physiology, and immunity, infection, and therapeutics are studied at a global scale. Our curriculum embeds values of inclusivity, equality and sustainability. In learning materials, we prioritise representation of diverse imagery and use scientific cases which reflect issues affecting marginalised communities.  

Attendance recorded: Yes

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
Cycle 1: On-line assessment - data analysis and interpretation

Cycle 2: Open-book extended written answer question under exam conditions (N.B. some concerns about module size/marking load)

Authentic assessment: There are two assessment strategies. Data interpretation is highly authentic and offers a comprehensive assessment of knowledge in different authentic contexts – problem-solving, critical thinking, project planning etc. The online tests require students to lead their own enquiry of the content and build a critical knowledge base which will be applied to subsequent modules. This fosters skills desirable in many sectors of employment and those of lifelong learning.  

Reassessment will use the same format but the topic or data will differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Information Processing by Cell Signalling Networks in Health and Disease 2026-27

Org Unit:Life Sciences NEW
Level:Level 6
Credits:15
Module Code:BIOS331
Delivery:Liverpool campus · Semester 1
 
In Programmes:Pharmacology BSc (Hons) 2024-25
Biomedical Sciences BSc (Hons) 2024-25
Microbiology and Infection BSc (Hons) 2024-25
Biochemistry BSc (Hons) 2024-25
Details
Module Title
Information Processing by Cell Signalling Networks in Health and Disease
Short Title
How do cells make decisions?
Module Code
BIOS331
Academic Year
2026-27
Org Unit
Life Sciences NEW
Delivery Locations
Liverpool campus
Delivery Periods
Semester 1
Credits
15
Level
Level 6
Module Coordinator
Terrence Gleave
Other Staff

Ian Prior
Judy Coulson

Quality Team
Status
 
Approved
Date of Approval
15 Jan 2024, 10:47
External Examiner(s)
Leda Mirbahai
Continuing Professional Development
No
Maximum Places
350
Pre-requisites
Cellular Basis of Health and Disease 2025-26
HESA Cost Centres
Biosciences
Blurb
Overview
This module will build on concepts introduced in BIOS209: Cellular Basis of Health and Disease, to develop an in-depth understanding of modern ideas in cell signalling in both health and disease. It will provide students with the ability to access, collate and discuss the modern literature in cell signalling from both molecular and systems physiology perspectives. Students will be introduced to cutting-edge research about how signalling networks are dynamically integrated to control biological processes. Students will be taught aspects of fundamental cellular signalling processes, that are essential for life and often disrupted in disease.

The module will be taught through a series of 20 x 1 hour lectures and 10 x 1 hour tutorials, delivered by experts in their respective fields, and self-directed learning.

Assessment will be split into two cycles: Cycle 1 will be a written assignment, delivered online, based on data analysis and interpretation. Cycle 2 will be an open-book assessment, taken under exam conditions, in the form of extended written piece of work.
Educational Aims
This module aims to:
Develop knowledge and skills to enable the students to describe advanced concepts that are fundamental to modern ideas in cellular dynamics, biophysics and cell signalling from a systems physiology perspective covering both physiology and disease;

Develop the ability to apply, evaluate and interpret this knowledge and understanding;

Develop in students the ability to access, collate, critically evaluate, and discuss, in writing, the modern literature in cell signalling;

Enable students to acquire the skills required for interpretation of cell signalling experimental data and to integrate this knowledge in a physiological context.
Marketing Module Synopsis
Cell signalling networks allow individual cells to communicate with each other to coordinate their behaviour, maintain homeostasis, and respond to changes in their environment. This transfer of information from one cell to another, through the use of signalling molecules such as hormones, neurotransmitters, and growth factors is fundamental to modern ideas in cellular dynamics, biophysics and cell signalling in both health and disease.

This module will provide students with the ability to access, collate and discuss the modern literature in cell signalling from a systems physiology perspective by active research staff using relevant examples from their own research. Successful students will develop the skills required for interpretation of experimental cell signalling data. The module will be taught through a series of lectures and tutorials and will be assessed by both open book assessments. Cycle one will be an online assessment, with a focus on data analysis and interpretation; cycle 2 will be continuous assessment, under examination conditions, in the form of an extended piece of writing.
Outline Syllabus
The syllabus explores concepts fundamental to modern ideas in cell signalling. It will consider the major signalling pathways, and discuss specific examples of human diseases or physiological processes that utilise these generic pathways.

1. Feedback Mechanisms

Feedback mechanisms play a crucial role in regulating cell signalling pathways. Positive feedback amplifies the signal and increases the response, while negative feedback dampens the signal and reduces the response. This allows cells to fine-tune their responses to external stimuli and maintain a balance between opposing signals. Dynamic integration of feedback mechanisms fine tunes cellular outputs.

2. Spatial constraints

Cells are organised into specific tissues and organs, and signalling molecules must be able to reach their target cells within these structures. For example, nerve cells must communicate over long distances, while immune cells must communicate with neighbouring cells to coordinate their responses to pathogens.
Spatial and temporal regulation at a subcellular level, in order to control dynamic cellular processes, will also be considered.

3. Crosstalk between signalling pathways

Different pathways may interact with each other, either by amplifying or inhibiting their effects. This allows cells to integrate multiple signals and respond appropriately to complex stimuli.

4. Timing of Response

Many signalling pathways are activated rapidly in response to a stimulus, but then quickly deactivated to prevent overstimulation. This allows cells to respond to changing conditions and maintain proper function. Additionally, signalling pathways can be activated at specific times during development or in response to specific cues, allowing for precise control over cellular processes.
Themes 1-4 will allow students to appreciate a 4-dimensional model of cell signalling.

5. Therapeutic Intervention

Cellular Signalling is a complex process that involves feedback mechanisms, spatial constraints, crosstalk between pathways, and precise timing. Students will develop an understanding of how knowledge of these aspects of cell signalling can be harnessed to develop effective therapies for diseases that arise from dysregulation of these pathways.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Learning and teaching on this module will be delivered by live on-campus sessions (lectures & guided workshops), supplemented by asynchronous online preparatory material made available 1 week before the on-campus sessions.

Online Preparatory Material:  
This is the form of online reading, multimedia and small tasks to introduce key concepts and prepares students for the block of upcoming lectures.  
 
Lectures:  
The module will be taught through lectures with an emphasis towards student participation. These will cover the core module content and characterised by interactive group discussions and activities to enhance understanding of key concepts. 20 x 1 hour teaching sessions will be delivered over a twelve-week period.  
The synchronous on-campus lectures will provide new learning material but will also be an opportunity to discuss points raised in the asynchronous material. Focus will particularly be on research methodologies and data interrogation & interpretation. Interactive discussion will be encouraged through activities delivered through platforms such as Polls Everywhere and discussion boards.

Guided workshops/ Tutorials: These will provide opportunities for students to work with research staff in research-connected activities related to the summative assessments.

Self-directed learning: Guided and self-directed reading, reflection on learning, formative assessment (quizzes, discussion questions for synchronous sessions) and preparation for summative assessments.
The module is designed to incorporate the hallmarks of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework, in the following ways: 
 
Research-connected teaching: Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active/ connected scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence. Core concepts are contextualised with publications of recent scientific research. Assessment submissions from learners should be evidence-based by their exploration of primary literature, and suitably referenced.  

Inclusivity and accessibility: Resource templates use accessible fonts and colour schemes. Content is uploaded to the VLE in advance, in a format compatible with assistive technologies and checked proactively with Ally. Format adjustments are also available on request in accordance with specific learning disabilities and support plans. Lectures are recorded and available on the VLE. 

Active learning: Structured participation will be interactive, using quizzes (e.g. PollEverywhere, Mentimeter, Kahoot) and collaborative, interactive tools (e.g. Padlet, Miro). Formative exercises will provide students with regular feedback on their learning. 

Confidence: This is developed continuously throughout the module. Lectures are discursive and interactive, with learners contributing ideas and analysis to ongoing discussion. This builds confidence by creating a ‘safe space’ for sharing of ideas and expertise.  

Digital fluency: Digital fluency is encouraged through a combination of methods. The VLE is used for formative and summative assessment in the form of interactive quizzes. Assessment activity also requires students to develop competency with digital technology. 
 
Global citizenship: Organisms, their development, their varied physiology, and immunity, infection, and therapeutics are studied at a global scale. Our curriculum embeds values of inclusivity, equality and sustainability. In learning materials, we prioritise representation of diverse imagery and use scientific cases which reflect issues affecting marginalised communities.  

Attendance recorded: Yes

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
Cycle 1: On-line assessment - data analysis and interpretation

Cycle 2: Open-book extended written answer question under exam conditions (N.B. some concerns about module size/marking load)

Authentic assessment: There are two assessment strategies. Data interpretation is highly authentic and offers a comprehensive assessment of knowledge in different authentic contexts – problem-solving, critical thinking, project planning etc. The online tests require students to lead their own enquiry of the content and build a critical knowledge base which will be applied to subsequent modules. This fosters skills desirable in many sectors of employment and those of lifelong learning.  

Reassessment will use the same format but the topic or data will differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Admin

 LO3 Appraise the pathophysiological consequences of dysregulated cell signalling.
 LO4 Critically analyse experimental data relating to the study of cell signalling.

Blurb
Overview
This module will build on concepts introduced in BIOS209: Cellular Basis of Health and Disease, to develop an in-depth understanding of modern ideas in cell signalling in both health and disease. It will provide students with the ability to access, collate and discuss the modern literature in cell signalling from both molecular and systems physiology perspectives. Students will be introduced to cutting-edge research about how signalling networks are dynamically integrated to control biological processes. Students will be taught aspects of fundamental cellular signalling processes, that are essential for life and often disrupted in disease.

The module will be taught through a series of 20 x 1 hour lectures and 10 x 1 hour tutorials, delivered by experts in their respective fields, and self-directed learning.

Assessment will be split into two cycles: Cycle 1 will be a written assignment, delivered online, based on data analysis and interpretation. Cycle 2 will be an open-book assessment, taken under exam conditions, in the form of extended written piece of work.
Educational Aims
This module aims to:
Develop knowledge and skills to enable the students to describe advanced concepts that are fundamental to modern ideas in cellular dynamics, biophysics and cell signalling from a systems physiology perspective covering both physiology and disease;

Develop the ability to apply, evaluate and interpret this knowledge and understanding;

Develop in students the ability to access, collate, critically evaluate, and discuss, in writing, the modern literature in cell signalling;

Enable students to acquire the skills required for interpretation of cell signalling experimental data and to integrate this knowledge in a physiological context.
Marketing Module Synopsis
Cell signalling networks allow individual cells to communicate with each other to coordinate their behaviour, maintain homeostasis, and respond to changes in their environment. This transfer of information from one cell to another, through the use of signalling molecules such as hormones, neurotransmitters, and growth factors is fundamental to modern ideas in cellular dynamics, biophysics and cell signalling in both health and disease.

This module will provide students with the ability to access, collate and discuss the modern literature in cell signalling from a systems physiology perspective by active research staff using relevant examples from their own research. Successful students will develop the skills required for interpretation of experimental cell signalling data. The module will be taught through a series of lectures and tutorials and will be assessed by both open book assessments. Cycle one will be an online assessment, with a focus on data analysis and interpretation; cycle 2 will be continuous assessment, under examination conditions, in the form of an extended piece of writing.
Outline Syllabus
The syllabus explores concepts fundamental to modern ideas in cell signalling. It will consider the major signalling pathways, and discuss specific examples of human diseases or physiological processes that utilise these generic pathways.

1. Feedback Mechanisms

Feedback mechanisms play a crucial role in regulating cell signalling pathways. Positive feedback amplifies the signal and increases the response, while negative feedback dampens the signal and reduces the response. This allows cells to fine-tune their responses to external stimuli and maintain a balance between opposing signals. Dynamic integration of feedback mechanisms fine tunes cellular outputs.

2. Spatial constraints

Cells are organised into specific tissues and organs, and signalling molecules must be able to reach their target cells within these structures. For example, nerve cells must communicate over long distances, while immune cells must communicate with neighbouring cells to coordinate their responses to pathogens.
Spatial and temporal regulation at a subcellular level, in order to control dynamic cellular processes, will also be considered.

3. Crosstalk between signalling pathways

Different pathways may interact with each other, either by amplifying or inhibiting their effects. This allows cells to integrate multiple signals and respond appropriately to complex stimuli.

4. Timing of Response

Many signalling pathways are activated rapidly in response to a stimulus, but then quickly deactivated to prevent overstimulation. This allows cells to respond to changing conditions and maintain proper function. Additionally, signalling pathways can be activated at specific times during development or in response to specific cues, allowing for precise control over cellular processes.
Themes 1-4 will allow students to appreciate a 4-dimensional model of cell signalling.

5. Therapeutic Intervention

Cellular Signalling is a complex process that involves feedback mechanisms, spatial constraints, crosstalk between pathways, and precise timing. Students will develop an understanding of how knowledge of these aspects of cell signalling can be harnessed to develop effective therapies for diseases that arise from dysregulation of these pathways.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Learning and teaching on this module will be delivered by live on-campus sessions (lectures & guided workshops), supplemented by asynchronous online preparatory material made available 1 week before the on-campus sessions.

Online Preparatory Material:  
This is the form of online reading, multimedia and small tasks to introduce key concepts and prepares students for the block of upcoming lectures.  
 
Lectures:  
The module will be taught through lectures with an emphasis towards student participation. These will cover the core module content and characterised by interactive group discussions and activities to enhance understanding of key concepts. 20 x 1 hour teaching sessions will be delivered over a twelve-week period.  
The synchronous on-campus lectures will provide new learning material but will also be an opportunity to discuss points raised in the asynchronous material. Focus will particularly be on research methodologies and data interrogation & interpretation. Interactive discussion will be encouraged through activities delivered through platforms such as Polls Everywhere and discussion boards.

Guided workshops/ Tutorials: These will provide opportunities for students to work with research staff in research-connected activities related to the summative assessments.

Self-directed learning: Guided and self-directed reading, reflection on learning, formative assessment (quizzes, discussion questions for synchronous sessions) and preparation for summative assessments.
The module is designed to incorporate the hallmarks of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework, in the following ways: 
 
Research-connected teaching: Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active/ connected scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence. Core concepts are contextualised with publications of recent scientific research. Assessment submissions from learners should be evidence-based by their exploration of primary literature, and suitably referenced.  

Inclusivity and accessibility: Resource templates use accessible fonts and colour schemes. Content is uploaded to the VLE in advance, in a format compatible with assistive technologies and checked proactively with Ally. Format adjustments are also available on request in accordance with specific learning disabilities and support plans. Lectures are recorded and available on the VLE. 

Active learning: Structured participation will be interactive, using quizzes (e.g. PollEverywhere, Mentimeter, Kahoot) and collaborative, interactive tools (e.g. Padlet, Miro). Formative exercises will provide students with regular feedback on their learning. 

Confidence: This is developed continuously throughout the module. Lectures are discursive and interactive, with learners contributing ideas and analysis to ongoing discussion. This builds confidence by creating a ‘safe space’ for sharing of ideas and expertise.  

Digital fluency: Digital fluency is encouraged through a combination of methods. The VLE is used for formative and summative assessment in the form of interactive quizzes. Assessment activity also requires students to develop competency with digital technology. 
 
Global citizenship: Organisms, their development, their varied physiology, and immunity, infection, and therapeutics are studied at a global scale. Our curriculum embeds values of inclusivity, equality and sustainability. In learning materials, we prioritise representation of diverse imagery and use scientific cases which reflect issues affecting marginalised communities.  

Attendance recorded: Yes

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
Cycle 1: On-line assessment - data analysis and interpretation

Cycle 2: Open-book extended written answer question under exam conditions (N.B. some concerns about module size/marking load)

Authentic assessment: There are two assessment strategies. Data interpretation is highly authentic and offers a comprehensive assessment of knowledge in different authentic contexts – problem-solving, critical thinking, project planning etc. The online tests require students to lead their own enquiry of the content and build a critical knowledge base which will be applied to subsequent modules. This fosters skills desirable in many sectors of employment and those of lifelong learning.  

Reassessment will use the same format but the topic or data will differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Outcomes
Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcome 
 LO1 Explore and evaluate how cells receive information and transmit it along distinct pathways to generate different physiological responses.
 LO2 Critically discuss how post-translational modifications mediate information transfer, how the major kinase and second messenger pathways are stimulated and how they function in normal cells.
 LO3 Appraise the pathophysiological consequences of dysregulated cell signalling.
 LO4 Critically analyse experimental data relating to the study of cell signalling.
